resource.chars:
of all the Reds Then after a Lively Orange followed an 
intense, bright & copious Yellow, wch was also the best of 
all the Yellows; and this changed first to a greenish yellow 
& then to a greenish Blew; But the Green between the 
Yellow & blew was very little & dilute, Seeming rather a 
Greenish white then a Green. The blew wch Succeeded 
became very good & of a fair bright Sky colour; but yet Some 
thing inferiour to the former blew. And the violet was 
intense & deep with little or no Redness in it, And less in
quantity then the Blew.
In the last Red appeared a Tincture of Scarlet next 
the Violet, wch Soon changed to a brighter colour inclineing to a 
Orange, And the yellow wch followed was at first pretty good 
& lively, but afterwards it grew more & more dilute, untill 
by degrees it ended in p[er]fect whitenesse. And this whitenes[se?]
if the water was very tenacious & well tempered; would slow[ly]
spread & dilate it Self over the greatest part of the Bubble 
continually growing paler at the top, where at length it would 
crack in many places, & those cracks as they dilated would appe[ar]
of a pretty good, but yet obscure & dark Sky colour, the white 
between the blew spots diminishing untill it resembled the [text?]
of an irregular Nettworke & soon after vanished & left all the 
upper part of the Bubble of the said dark blew colour. And [the?]
colour after the aforesaid manner dilated it Selfe downwards 
untill Somtimes it hath overspread the whole Bubble. In the 
mean while at the topp, wch was of a darker Blew then the 
bottome & appeared also of many round blew Spots Something 
darker then the rest, there would Emerge one or more very 
black Spots, & within those, other Spots of an Intenser black[nes?]
wch I menc[i]oned in the former observac[i]on; And those continually 
dilated themselves untill the Bubble broak.
If the water was not very tenacious, the black Spots would 
break forth in the white without any Sensible Intervenc[i]on of 
the blew: And Somtimes they would break forth within the 
precedent Yellow, or Red, or p[er]haps within the Blew of the 2d
Order before the intermediate colours had time to display 
themselues.
By this description you may p[er]ceive, how great an affinity 
these colours haue with those of Air described in the fourth 
Observac[i]on, although Sett downe in a contrary Order by reason 
that they begin to appear when the Bubble is thickest & are 
most conveniently reckoned from the lowest & thickest part
of the Bubble upwards
Obs: 19. Viewing at Seu[er?]all Oblique Positions of 
my eye the Rings of colours Emergeing on the Top of the 
Bubble
